talk.start.para: Victoria)-I give notice that on the next day of sitting, I shall move: That the Senate is of the opinion—

item.para: That the right of senators to question Ministers is limited only by the judgment of the Senate and that Ministers ought to answer questions with a promptness and accuracy appropriate to ministerial responsibility:
That any practice by Ministers prefacing or interpolating in answers to Senate questions offensive or insulting comments about senators asking questions is contrary to best parliamentary practice.

talk.start.para: I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

question.para: Is the Government aware that prior to the overthrow of the Allende Government in Chile last September, persons who had been involved in terrorist and urban guerrilla activities in South America had been accepted as citizens of Chile? Is the Government not also aware that many of these persons are now refugees from Chile, being persons who do not prefer to live in Chile or who are not prepared to be accepted as citizens of Chile by the new Government? Is it not a fact that members of the Australian Government are sympathetic to the cause of these persons? In view of the Government's admission made within the last week that 228 refugees from Chile are to be admitted to Australia, and in the light of the Government's sympathies, and restrictions which have been placed upon the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, what positive assurance is the Minister able to give that terrorists and guerrillas will not be admitted to Australia?

talker.electorate: New South WalesLeader of the Government in the Senate

talk.start.para: A number of matters are involved in the question. 1 think it would be satisfactory, out of deference to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, for the question to be placed on the notice paper and a considered answer given to it.

Ltd for a major steel making plant in Western Australia. 1 direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate in the hope that he will be able to cast light on circumstances which, to me, are the most extraordinary that 1 have ever heard of in my period as a

question.para: member of the Senate. Yesterday I asked the Leader of the Government whether he would guarantee that sufficient time would be available for the preparation of the No case for the proposed referenda. I quote from his statement:

quote.para: But I assure the honourable senator that they will be given the opportunity to prepare . . . They know that thc referenda are to be dealt with al thc May election. I understand that some approach will probably be made io the Leader of the Opposition by the Prime Minister to get him to deal with the question from the Opposition side.

question.para: That is a clear statement by the Leader of the Government that the matter has not yet been set on foot.

talk.start.para: Ask the question, Senator

I ask this question: Are the statements made to me correct, namely, that the Leader of the Opposition had been approached before the Leader of the Government in the Senate assured me that he was going to be approached? Has he been in the position of preparing the No case for some days? Has the Leader of the Opposition in another place been informed that the No case has to be ready by tomorrow? Is it a fact that the approach to the Leader of the Opposition in another place was made without any reference to the Leader of the Australian Country Party or to the Leader of the Australian Democratic Labor Party? Is it the attitude of the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Leader of the Liberal Party in another place that the Country Party and the Democratic Labor Party can be ignored in all the arrangements in regard to the referenda?

talker.electorate: New South WalesLeader of the Government in the Senate
talker.name: MURPHY, Lionel
Senator MURPHY

talk.start.para: The Leader of the Australian Democratic Labor Party says that it is the most extraordinary circumstance with which he has been associated in all his time here as a senator. Probably that should amaze us all because he has been associated with many extraordinary episodes. I stand here and try to assist the Leader of the Democratic Labor Party as I try to assist all honourable senators, to the best of my knowledge. Sometimes I do not have the required information in writing before me, but I try to help. My understanding was that the Leader of the Oppositional d I meant in the House of Representatives—ha d been or was being approached about the matter. Senator McManus has told us that he has been preparing the No case for some days. Apparently he has not seen fit to consult those who assisted him in preventing the legislation being put through this House. If there is this terrible breakdown, lack of confidence, or even lack of consultation, all we can do is sympathise with the DLP and its Leader

answer.para: and assure him that we would not countenance such a lack of consultation or lack of confidence.

talk.start.para: - Why did you tell me that it had not been done when it had been done? You told me that they had not even approached him.

talker.electorate: New South WalesLeader of the Government in the Senate
talker.name: MURPHY, Lionel

My information was gained orally and in passing, lf Senator McManus found out for himself that the Leader had been approached, it would not matter except, as he points out, for the dreadful fact that he has been going ahead to prepare a case without even consulting with Senator McManus. Let us put the blame where it correctly lies. It is a relatively unimportant aspect that I was not in a position to tell the honourable senator that in fact the Leader of the Opposition had been approached rather than indicate that he was being or would be approached. As Senator McManus properly points out, the real basis is that the Leader of the Opposition is not even bothering to consult Senator McManus or to take him into his confidence.
Order! Senator Murphy, I think you are beginning to debate the question

My question is directed to the Minister for the Media. I refer to the report and recommendations concerning the Australian Broadcasting Commission made by the management consultants Mckinney and Co., incorporated and tabled by he Minister yesterday. Is the Minister aware that at about 3 p.m. yesterday I received an invitation from the ABC to take part in a discussion on last night's 'This Day Tonight' program together with Professor Downing, Chairman of the ABC and Mr Phillip Adams, the well known critic and film producer? Is the Minister aware that, after I had spent 2 hours reading the report to equip myself to take part in the discussion I was advised by the ABC, without apology or explanation, that its invitation was withdrawn? Was the Minister consulted by the ABC either about the invitation to me or about the withdrawal of the invitation? Does the Minister agree that parliamentarians who make themselves available

question.para: for interview on television or radio at the ABC's request, and often at considerable personal inconvenience, are entitled to more courteous treatment by the Commission? Will the Minister ask the General Manager of the ABC to let me know the reason why the invitation was so discourteously withdrawn?

talk.start.para: I was not aware that my colleague, Senator James McClelland, was approached at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon about appearing on the television program 'This Day Tonight' to discuss with others the terms of the Mckinney Report that I tabled in Parliament yesterday. I can tell the honourable senator that I was approached at about 5 o'clock and asked whether I would be prepared to appear on that television program. I told the person who approached me on behalf of the Australian Broadcasting Commission that for personal reasons I was unable to do so. I was subsequently informed that Professor Downing, the Chairman of the ABC, and Mr Phillip Adams, the Chairman of the Film and Television Board of the Australian Council for the Arts, would be appearing on the program to discuss the Mckinney Report. I will certainly make inquiries on behalf of my colleague and let the honourable senator know the outcome.

Is the Minister representing the Minister for Labour aware that the present closure of the electrolytic zinc works at Risdon in Tasmania is now of 2 weeks in length and that in that time, when ordinary workers are receiving no money, those who contrived and control the unrest continue to be paid? Is the Minister aware that the action of these few people is now resulting in thousands of others in the community—man y of them just ordinary consumers, railway workers, paper makers farmers and their families—bein g deprived of their livelihood? Does the Minister realise that the dispute is really between the union organisers and the Tasmanian Labor Government-established tribunal, the State Wages Board? Can the Federal Minister for Labour intervene urgently so that common sense will prevail and those people who have wangled their way into the unions in Tasmama, after coming from other areas, can be sent packing and despatched from our community which was quite happy until they arrived?
Las t week, Senator Wright asked me a question relating to this dispute. After question time I obtained information from the Minister for Labour about the dispute

answer.para: which revealed that the workers come under a State award. The Minister for Labour indicated that he could not intervene in the dispute even if he so desired. The parties were then engaging in conferences which were convened by the State Minister for Labour and also by the Chairman of the State Wages Board. It was hoped that some solution would be found. I am told also that there is to be another conference today. However much the Commonwealth Minister for Labour wants to intervene in this matter he is not able to do so unless he is requested by the employers and the unions jointly to intervene and perhaps to provide the facilities of the Commonwealth arbitration inspectors or conciliators for that purpose.

talk.start.para: - What about his troubleshooter, Mr Foster? What trouble has he shot?

As you are aware, Senator McManus, I am quite sure that if the State Labor Government, the unions and the employers said they would like to use the facilities of the Commonwealth Department, and have the assistance of Mr Clyde Cameron and Mr Foster— I might indicate that I too would volunteer for the purpose of helping to settle the dispute—tha t request would be met. It is unfortunate that the dispute has lasted for so long. All I can say to Senator Townley is that unless a request is received from the unions, the employers or the State Government, the Commonwealth Minister has no power to intervene in this particular dispute.

My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, both in that capacity and also as Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the decision of the Government to maintain the policy of requiring a deposit of one-third of any overseas borrowings which are in Australia. I ask: In view of the devastating effect which that policy has had on the Al west project in Western Australia and of the likely similar effects which such a policy would have on other projects of that nature in Australia, is the Government prepared to reconsider the wisdom of that policy?

talker.electorate: New South WalesLeader of the Government in the Senate
talker.name: MURPHY, Lionel
Senator MURPHY

talk.start.para: The Treasurer at all times has all aspects of the monetary policies of the Government under consideration. I think the honourable senator can take it fbr granted that all these matters would be under almost continuous review. I am not suggesting that there is some likelihood of any change, but certainly the Treasurer is managing the economy as best he can within the limited powers that the Federal

answer.para: Government has. I am quite sure that that aspect of those policies, as well as others, will be taken into consideration and will be reviewed constantly by him.

talk.start.para: I direct a question to the Minister for the Media. By way of very brief preface, I refer to the fact that recently the daily Press has carried advertisements setting out the practices of the Australian Parliament. I imagine that the advertisements are designed to make the Australian community better informed of the workings of this Parliament. Will the advertisements on the functions and workings of the Australian parliamentary system be available in collected form for use in schools or libraries at a later date? Is the Department of the Media involved in making any other educational material available to schools?

I can tell the honourable senators that, as part of the machinery of government advertising, the wording of advertisements setting out the workings of Parliament were prepared by parliamentary officers and approved by Mr President and Mr Speaker, and they were inserted by the Australian Government. I can tell the honourable senator that as a result of these advertisements being inserted last week, there has been considerable public demand, especially from teachers and educationists, for these advertisements to be put in booklet form. It is intended by my Department that the first 10 of these advertisements relating to the Houses of Parliament will eventually be made ava dab le as a set for general educational purposes. I can also tell the honourable senator that my Department is at the moment undertaking a series of projects designed to meet the important educational need by providing material for media studies to Australian secondary schools. As part of that project, this year 2,000 booklets will be prepared in the form of radio broadcasting media kits for distribution in secondary schools throughout Australia

My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration. Does the Government's recent announcement of intention to bring to Australia skilled Filipino migrants mean that the Government is embarking on a campaign to recruit skilled persons from Asia and the Pacific? Is the principle to be applied to all countries of the

question.para: region? Does it mean that the Government intends a change the composition of the Australian people? If not, what does it mean?

talk.start.para: The matter to which the honourable senator referred arises, I think, as a result of a request from one country to another. The request having been made and discussions having taken place between the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Government steps are being taken to ensure that those coming to Australia to occupy certain positions in this country have the requisite trade skills. As I said recently in answer to a question by another honourable senator, I think it fair to say that the Government adopts the attitude that all requests for migration to Australia will be based on the needs of Australia and on the merits of the individual application, and the requirements of the work force in this country will certainly be taken into account.

Doe s the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory know that in October or November last year New York State reduced its speed limit from 65 miles per hour to 55 miles per hour only because of the fuel shortage in America at that time? Does he know that this 10 mile per hour reduction in the speed limit produced a startling result in that the death rate on the roads in that State was reduced within a month by 20 to 25 per cent, resulting in the saving of nearly 1,000 lives? This was reported in the 'New York Times'. I ask the Minister: As the reduction of the maximum speed limit by only 10 miles per hour produced such a startling result in America within one month, will he introduce similar legislation in this Parliament and also strictly enforce all speed limits with the certain knowledge that by so doing he will, without any doubt, save lives on Australian roads and help to reduce the shocking road toll? I further ask the Minister: In an endeavour to make speed limits uniform throughout Australia, will he include in that legislation the following provision which was introduced and passed unanimously in the American Parliament on 3 December 1973:

quote.para: This law requires all States to establish a uniform speed limit of 55 miles per hour, and any State that does not comply within 60 days will be penalised by the loss of all Federal Funds for Highway projects.

talk.start.para: By so doing the States will be obliged to reduce their speed limits and thus help to save human lives.

talker.electorate: New South WalesLeader of the Government in the Senate
talker.name: MURPHY, Lionel
Senator MURPHY

talk.start.para: I am indebted to the honourable senator for his information. I inform

answer.para: the Senate that a standing committee of Attorneys-General of Australia, the States, and New Zealand met a few weeks ago. When I was in New Zealand figures were published there of the death and injury rate from road accidents. As I recall it, during the months of this year there had been a dramatic fall in the death and injury rate. I think the figure was about half of what it had been in the previous year. This seemed to be associated directly with the lowered speed limit which had been applied. So I have no doubt that what the honourable senator is putting is correct. I have spoken to the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Bryant, about the experience in New Zealand. He has it in mind to introduce measures to help to curb the death and injury rate on the roads and the speed limit is in the forefront of his mind. I shall take into consideration the honourable senator's suggestion about using the allocation of Federal funds to induce the States to do likewise, but already we have heard the reaction of some honourable senators that even though lives will be saved in considerable numbers such action could represent an unpardonable intrusion upon the rights of the States.

talk.start.para: I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Labour whether he will consider streamlining facilities available at Commonwealth employment centres in view of complaints of delays by persons who are awaiting interviews.

I will refer the question to the Minister for Labour. I have heard reports about congestion which occurs sometimes at Commonwealth employment centres. Recently the Minister for Labour introduced an innovation in South Australia when he set up what he called a self service employment service. There, because of the small staff involved, it is possible to have a number of indexes and listings of job vacancies. Employees in the area can look at the job vacancies, see what is available and make their own application. That is an innovation. I shall find out whether that system is to be developed in other areas and let the honourable senator know about it.

I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate, who represents the Prime Minister: On what grounds are the accusations made that the Alcoa mining operations in Western Australia are endangering the Perth

Does not the Prime Minister's statement infer that the Department of Environmental Protection in Western Australia has failed in its task of protecting the environment and water supplies in the Darling Range on both the Alcoa and Al west mining leases? What are the far more meritorious cases than Al west that the Prime Minister referred to?

talk.start.para: The honourable senator raised a very technical question. I think it ought to be dealt with on the basis of the technical knowledge that is available and in the light of scientific considerations rather than on the basis of politics. My understanding is that a matter of quite serious concern is involved in Western Australia and that it touches upon the future of water supplies. The question of salinity and the effect that the removal of the jarrah forests may have upon the salinity of the water is involved. I think it would be better if the question were referred to the Minister for the Environment and Conservation, and to the Minister for Science as I understand that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is involved in this matter in some way, so that a detailed reply can be given to the honourable senator.

I ask the Minister for Primary Industry whether it is a fact that in March 1973 the Government reviewed with the States the rural reconstruction scheme and that it continued the scheme for another year? Can the Minister say what is the current situation, and whether another review is to be held in the near future, and what is the future of rural reconstruction?

It is an annual event for the Australian Government to hold consultations with the State governments in respect of rural reconstruction. That meeting normally takes place in April each year. New discussions will be taking place within the next 2 or 3 weeks. As for the future of the scheme, so far as the Australian Government is concerned it will continue in much the same form as we have seen in the past. I am sure that we will receive the co-operation of the States in pursuing that end.

I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Labour. Yesterday he answered questions I asked about the Electrolytic Zinc Co. dispute. It was mentioned also by Senator Townley. Does the Minister not understand that the real issue

question.para: there is an attempt by the unions to force disputes out of the jurisdiction of the State Wages Boards? Will he, as a representative of the Labor Party, the creature of the trade union organisations, assist the State Labor Government to maintain the authority of the Wages Board? Does he know that this Government is paralysing the shipping services to Tasmania, that 14,000 tons of newsprint have accumulated at Australian Newsprint Mills Ltd 15 miles up the Derwent River, and that unless it is shifted by the end of the month that enterprise, employing 1,500 people, is threatened with a shut-down? Will he do something to keep peace in industry and let men work?

talk.start.para: It seems unusual for Senator Wright, one of those people in this Senate who rise and talk about the dangers of centralism, to ask the Commonwealth Minister for Labour now to intervene in a State dispute. I already have made an offer to Senator Wright. I said to Senator Townley that if the State authorities, the employers and the unions wanted the Commonwealth Government to intervene in the dispute I was sure that the Minister for Labour, Mr Clyde Cameron, would be only too pleased to do so. Senator McManus introduced the argument that we might use Mr Foster. I said also that in my capacity as an old union official I would be prepared to try to settle any dispute. We cannot do more than that since it is a State dispute. However the Commonwealth Government would be pleased to assist the State Government or the State tribunals in settling the dispute. I know that the responsible State Minister and the State Wages Board have been trying to resolve it. I am also aware that another conference is to be held today. If the authorities cannot settle the dispute and if the State Premier wants us to intervene, I would recommend to the Federal Minister to do all that he can to settle it.

Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware that 2 political prisoners, both Chileans and members of the Movement of the Revolutionary Left— a legal political party in the recoup period—ar e under sentence of death by the illegal military clique which overthrew the properly constituted and democratically elected government in Chile? In view of the consistent attitude taken by the Australian

question.para: Government to help all political prisoners, will the Minister ask the Prime Minister to intercede on behalf of these two persons and request a stay of the execution of all political dissenters in Chile and offer these two persons political asylum in Australia?

talk.start.para: I am not aware of the details of the matter raised by the honourable senator, but I shall bring the matter immediately to the attention of the Prime Minister in his capacity as Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs.

What is meant by the Minister's statement in the letter'to develop further policies which will reduce the toll of death and injury on the roads'?

The Australian Transport Advisory Council, which comprises the Federal and State Ministers for Transport, meets to determine in what areas the allocation of funds should be made for road safety education. It seems that these days we are all becoming centra lists. The suggestion now is that the Australian Government should direct how money allocated for this purpose is spent in South Australia. If this necessitates the allocation of funds, the Australian Government meets the requirements of the States so that they can implement their safety measures

I direct a question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister believe that he is reflecting the view of the majority of Australians in seeking to prevent the United States from setting up a naval installation on Diego Garcia, although this installation would help to keep the American presence in the Indian Ocean which is strategically vital to Australia? Why has the Prime

question.para: Minister never made any formal protest to the Soviet Union against the extension of Soviet naval power in the Indian Ocean, which the Prime Minister presumably wants to neutralise, although Soviet naval power is the prior operative cause of the building of the American installation? Further, in view of the fact that, without protest from the Australian Government, the Soviet is increasing the number of its surface naval vessels in the Indian Ocean and that the Australian Government is opposed to a balancing United States naval presence, will the Prime Minister state what steps he proposes to take (a) to build a balancing Australian naval force; (b) to expedite the building of the naval base at Cockburn Sound; and (c) to ensure that Australia takes every possible step to maintain its control over the Cocos Islands as an essential staging base?

talker.electorate: New South WalesLeader of the Government in the Senate
talker.name: MURPHY, Lionel
Senator MURPHY

talk.start.para: I think all Australia accepts that the Prime Minister has presented Australia's views on these matters of defence and foreign affairs in an independent, forthright and courageous manner. He will continue to do so. What he says and what he does are in Australia's interests. I am not aware of the precise details of all the matters that the honourable senator raises; he is aware that this is not one of my responsibilities. I will refer the matter to the Prime Minister, who is now also Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs; and if he would like to comment further on the honourable senator's remarks, I will convey that further comment to the honourable senator and to the Senate.

talk.start.para: The Copyright Act comes under my administration. The Attorney- General's Department has studied closely developments following upon public discussion last year of the market agreement between British publishers. British and Australian publishers conferred last September and as a result some changes were made to the market agreement for the benefit of Australian publishers. British publishers made recommendations to their members aimed at speeding up the availability of editions on the Australian market. Whilst these changes are to be commended some sections of the Australian community believe that they did not go far enough and will not overcome the problems that gave rise to the criticism of the market agreement. The Library Association is concerned that the changes will not afford any substantial

answer.para: benefit to many of the smaller libraries, including school and public libraries, and the members of the public they serve. If this is well founded then the consuming public might also be at a disadvantage.

My Department is making arrangements for a conference to be held in Sydney next month at which representatives with a wide variety of viewpoints will speak on these matters. The importation provisions of the Copyright Act relating to books and the closed market situation will be discussed. My Department is taking steps to ensure that all interested persons, including members of the public at large, may participate. I expect a report of the conference to be made to me and on the basis of that report I hope to come to some conclusion on whether the present law and administration are adequate and whether any changes ought to be made in either the law or the administration.

talk.start.para: I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Is the Minister aware that Victoria receives the lowest proportional financial benefit of any of the States under the Commonwealth Bureau of Roads report? I will give 2 examples. Is the Minister aware that the per capita grant to Victoria is only $21.2 but that to Western Australia is $44, and that the per vehicle grant to Victoria is only $57.6 but to Tasmania is $ 113? Can the Minister explain why the social, cultural, economic and political heart of the nation receives such unfair treatment from this Government?

The social conscience and heart of the nation, I think, receive possibly a smaller allocation because of the needs of such a State. I have reagan d 1 have with me briefings for a reply to a question which I expected— a report stating that Victoria was very much lagging behind and that it had criticised the slowness of the allocation of funds. The Minister for Transport had written to a number of States seeking a reply as to the money required. Whilst the Minister did receive replies from all States— I believe it was in December—Victori a was somewhat behind the other States in replying. The allocation of money for transport purposes is carried out under the same circumstances as an allocation of money for housing or any other allocation, namely, by agreement with the States. I would say that the proportion of the money made available or allocated would be in accordance with the needs of the States, in agreement with the Commonwealth Minister.

Does the Minister for Primary Industry recall a question asked yesterday by Senator Reid in which he said that the Pastoralists and Graziers Association of Western Australia was dissatisfied with the new wheat stabilisation scheme? What is the attitude to the scheme of the West Australian Farmers Union which is far more representative of wheat growers than the organisation mentioned by Senator Reid? Are there any issues still to be resolved between yourself and the Western Australian Government on wheat?

Yes , I recall the question asked yesterday by Senator Reid. It is true that the West Australian Farmers Union does represent a wider cross-section of primary producers in that State than does the Pastoralists and Graziers Association. The West Australian Farmers Union has endorsed the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation's acceptance of the new wheat stabilisation scheme. I think it is pleasing to note that the West Australian Farmers Union recognises the fact that there was a considerable amount of give and take on both sides during the course of those negotiations. Insofar as the position of the Western Australian Government is concerned, I state that there are now no outstanding differences between the Western Australian Government and the Australian Government in respect of the stabilisation scheme.

I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Urban and Regional Development. Is it a fact that the Albury-Wodonga development plan provides for 5 sites for government schools on a total area of 25 acres? In view of the readily available land in the proposed Albury-Wodonga area and in view of the fact that the educational facilities research laboratory has suggested that at least 8 acres is required for every 500 pupils and a further acre for each 100 pupils above that figure, will the Minister see that his colleague investigates to find out whether this is correct and also reconsiders the position so that the situation will not be that inadequate sites will bug and hamper the future education of children in that area?

I can assure the honourable senator that to the best of my knowledge Albury-Wodonga will be established on the best, modern town planning principles to meet all the requirements and facilities required in the

answer.para: area. If a recommendation has been made that 8 acres is needed for every 500 pupils, and this has not been applied, I will certainly take up the matter with the Minister and get him to look into it.

talk.start.para: Can the Minister for the Media say whether negotiations are still proceeding between the Australian Broadcasting Commission and the Victorian Football League for the right to telecast the Australian Rules replays? If so, when is an agreement likely to be reached?

I understand that negotiations are still proceeding between the Victorian Football League on the one hand and Channels 2 and 7 on the other hand concerning the possibility of negotiating a settlement on replay rights for the Victorian Football League football this year. I am hopeful that those negotiations will be settled some time today and that an announcement will be made later on.

My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Tourism and Recreation also has a sporting flavour. In respect to the announcement that Australian flags will be made available free of charge by the Australian Government to national sporting bodies, can the Minister give or obtain a definition of a national sporting body? To partly express the problem as I see it, I ask: Would one flag be available to the Australian Cricket Board of Control, which I assume has one, and, say, one to the Australian National Football Council, or would the representatives of those bodies in each town, city or State, be eligible for a free Australian flag?

I have not been provided with precise details of the statement of my colleague the Minister for Tourism and Recreation. Just off the cuff 1 would assume that a national sporting body would be one which operated on a national basis. However, that is only my interpretation. All I can do is undertake to raise the matter with my colleague in another place and obtain an answer for the honourable senator.

I address my question to the Minister for Customs and Excise. Last week I asked a question of the Minister on the serious and increasing problem of the use of the drug heroin. The Minister informed me that some

question.para: investigations were being pursued in co-operation with agencies overseas. Can the Minister say whether only specific investigations are undertaken, or does Australian activity extend to wider action on the drug problem on an international basis?

talker.electorate: New South WalesLeader of the Government in the Senate
talker.name: MURPHY, Lionel
Senator MURPHY

talk.start.para: It extends to wider action. Almost all the hard drugs being distributed illicitly in Australia—especiall y hero income from outside this country. For this reason it is necessary that our interest be extended to other countries, particularly in South East Asia. We have been encouraging an active and co-operative effort at all levels. During the recent visit of the Prime Minister to South East Asia he had significant discussions about this problem with some Heads of State. As honourable senators may be aware, Australia is a member of the United Nauons Commission on Narcotic Drugs. At the twenty-fifth session of the Commission in January last year Australia initiated a proposal to establish a special committee for the Far East region to make a study of the drug problem in this area.

answer.para: Australia was appointed Chairman and in June the Economic and Social Council approved a tour of the region by the Committee. The report of the Committee was presented to a special session of the Commission on Narcotic Drugs recently concluded in Geneva. The Commission agreed with the recommendations in the report and will shortly seek the agreement to it of the Economic and Social Council. It is expected that as a result of this initiative there will be a significant improvement in lias ion on the drug problem in the South East Asian region.

talk.start.para: Does the Minister representing the Minister for Transport recall that on 12 December last year I asked a question relating to Adelaide Airport and requesting information whether the South Australian Government had approached the Commonwealth Government to have the airport declared an international terminal? Does he also recall that a few days ago he provided me with an answer dated 28 December from the Federal Minister for Transport? He may like to inform me why the answer took almost 3 months to reach my office. The Minister indicated in his reply that there has been an approach by the South Australian Government for the Adelaide Airport to be made an international airport. I am quoting from the Minister's letter.
Order! Ask your question
It it important that I quote this passage.

I bow to your wish and to the Standing Orders. I mentioned the part that I wanted to mention, anyway. Is the Minister aware that the Premier of South Australia in answer to a question asked on Wednesday of last week on the same subject by Mr Becker, the honourable member for Hanson, stated that there had been no approach by the South Australian Government with respect to this matter. I am rather confused about the subject at this stage and I would like the Minister to tell me which statement is accurate. If the statement of the Federal Minister is not accurate, I would like to know what approaches have been made with respect to an international airport in South Australia.

I do not recall the details of the letter to which the honourable senator has referred. I presume that he referred to a question on notice. Obviously when the Parliament was prorogued the questions on notice were taken off the notice paper. A reply was sent as an act of courtesy. I cannot account for any delay which occurred in this respect. Apparently the honourable senator complains of some remarks in the letter contradictory to what the Premier of South Australia said. He refers to what the Minister said to the Premier of South Australia and immediately asks whether the Federal Minister is truthful in his letter and seeks to know what is the actual position. If the answer is interpreted correctly, I do not think that there is a contradiction between what was said by the Minister and by the Premier of South Australia. The answer necessarily expresses a truthful reply to the question in the way in which it was addressed.I will look into the matter and find out whether there are any other details.
