talk.start.para: - I take the unusual course, for me, of speaking on. the first reading of this Bill, which is a money Bill which the Senate may not amend. I do so in order to point out some features of the Bill. This Bill seeks parliamentary approval for an appropriation "of $ 168.575m for the payment of salaries and other related charges. It is an amount additional to that approved in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) passed on 29 November 1973, which should have lasted the Government until 30 June 1974. But, apparently, the fat cats have had more kittens than even the Labor Government expected. .

speech.para: The Opposition will not vote- against the Bill, because we do not believe that any citizen should suffer direct financial loss or embarrassment because of this Government's maladministration and financial lunacy. Ho weyer,, the Opposition wishes to take this opportunity to place on record its rejection of the Governments. reckless expan-sion of the Commonwealth Public Service. The Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam) may be nominally a republican, but at heart he is surely a true empire-builder. Just look at the Commonwealth Public Service. I say: 'What an empire'! How the Prime Minister has built upon it. Not only is it an expanding empire, but the Prime Minister sees it as a model empire, a pace-setting empire- and he certainly set quite a pace when he took over.

In the first 10 months of his reign the Prime Minister increased the number of government departments from 27 to 31 and created 95 boards, commissions of inquiry and task forces and 157 new divisions and branches of the Commonwealth Public Service. Furthermore, he increased the number of Second Division officers, on salaries ranging from $17,000 to $27,000 a year, by 205. On top of this, the Prime Minister has forecast that the Public Service will expand at the rate of 240 new public servants each week. I repeat: It is an expansion of 240 new public servants each week or, in his language, 5 per cent per annum. So far the cost to the public for these extra public servants is in the vicinity of $150m a year. This increase in the wages bill for the civilian Public Service is augmented by the general wage rises for all public servants and has sent the total bill for the Australian taxpayers from $569.9m in 1972-73 to $802.3m in 1973-74. That, Sir, is the cost that the rest of the Australian community has to bear. It is equal to an astronomical growth in the Public Service income expenditure of some 41 per cent in the current financial year.

The public servants are ripping off the Australian community. The only thing they add to the nation is wages and sadly enough the wages bill is not the end of this sorry story because there are ancillary services. Each public servant who puts a. foot outside his own town or city on official business is entitled to first class air travel- unlike the United States, the United Kingdom, New Zealand and many other countries where only very senior officers are entitled to travel first class, with economy class travel provided for other members of the Public Service. Every Commonwealth public servant is entitled to the most expensive form of travel. The Public Service Board estimated, as far back as 1972 that the total cost of air travel alone by Australian public servants in 1971-72 was approximately $9m in respect of domestic journeys and approximately $4m in respect of international journeys. The Board also estimated that if all these public servants had travelled economy class approximately $ 1.2m would have been saved on domestic journeys and $0.75m on international journeys. These figures were taken out before the great expansion in the Public Service, so today the savings would be very much greater.

Now let us take a look at housing and another hidden cost in the Public Service- a financial handout masquerading as regulation 97 allowances. For the uninitiated, regulation 97 is a housing subsidy which provides eligible married officers with $33 a week towards their rent if they have no children and $40 a week if they have children. The original purpose of the allowance was to help officers 'where the quarters provided are temporarily not available for occupancy, or where an officer, upon transfer, cannot enter into occupancy of quarters or private residence through unavoidable delay in the transmission of furniture and household effects'. The second sentence of that regulation provides:

item.para: . such allowance shall not be paid for more than 3 months except upon the approval of the Board.

speech.para: On 1 November 1973 there were 13 first level second division officers on $17,000 a year who were receiving the regulation 97 allowance.

talk.start.para: Forty dollars a week for rent?

That is right, and 4 of those officers had been subsidised for between 12 and 18 months and seven for more than 18 months. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a document, which was provided in answer to a question, showing the number of second and third division officers in receipt of regulation 97 allowances as at 1 November 1973.
Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.

-1 wonder how age or invalid pensioners would feel about this continuing handout to Commonwealth public servants? What would they think of this Government, which is supposed to be so interested in social welfare and which claims to have done so much in housing the poor? What would they think of this hypocritical Government which has insisted on continuing regulation 97 allowances for its greatly expanded, highly paid, pace-setting Public Service- a Government which is prepared to give to public servants who receive $17,000 a year, or more than $300 a week, an allowance of $40 a week towards housing? This Government is prepared to pay these officers weekly almost twice the old age pension so they can rent a house. Surely these officers on $17,000 a year should stop budging on the Australian taxpayers and should go to the private sector for their housing needs. Even under the escalating costs which have been prevalent since the Labor Government took office these officers should be able to meet their own housing needs. What does the Australian taxpayer who, after all, foots the bill for the Public Service, get for his money? He gets very little, for the service by its very nature is non-productive. Mr President, reluctantly we support this Bill which is only a partial repast for the Prime Minister's deliberately created, rapidly expanding, self-perpetuating, money-eating giant.

- I want to speak on another subject on the first reading of this Bill. I could answer well the arguments that have been put up by Senator Withers because most of the things he said were implemented by his Party when it was in office, but I have something far more important to discuss tonight. I refer to the victimisation of a member of the Australian Labor Party in the State of Victoria by an insurance company known as Federation Insurance Ltd which is directly associated with the financial activities of the Victorian branch of the Australian Country Party. I believe that the best way in which I can demonstrate the victimisation that has taken place is to read a statement from a gentleman by the name of Mr Brian Smith. I have his authority to use his name and to read into the record the statement that he gave me. It is prefaced with these words:

quote.para: Statement of facts involving political persecution by the Country Party's Victorian financial source. The Federation Insurance Limited, against the endorsed Australian Labor Party candidate for the Federal seat of Mallee.
I hereby state that all accusations made in this statement can be supported by factual proof contained in documents in my possession.

speech.para: It reads: 1, Brian Smith, the endorsed ALP candidate for the Federal seat of Mallee in the House of Representatives have been employed by the Federation Insurance Limited of 342-348 Flinders Street Melbourne since February 1972 as their resident inspector at Charlton.

I was informed by the companies Victorian Country Branch assistant manager, Mr Alan Gallagher upon my appointment that my job would involve addressing meetings of the Victorian Farmers Union and obtaining insurance business from their members.
About seven months after my appointment the Victorian Farmers Union broke away from the insurance arrangement with the Federation Insurance Limited.
The Federation Insurance Limited then began to rely heavily on members of the Victorian Country Party for continued support.
At a later stage in my remarks I will indicate the extent of that support. The statement continues:

quote.para: At about this time, Mr Tudor the Victorian Country Branch manager of the company, instructed me to accompany him to a Country Party meeting at Donald on 16 October 1972.
I was instructed to make myself available to accompany him to this meeting which took place at night in my own time. No overtime or like compensation was offered.
At this meeting I was asked to join the Country Party and assist in the 1972 Federal elections. I declined both offers.
I was a member of the Australian Labor Party at the time and was giving all the assistance to Brian Brooke the ALP endorsed candidate for Wimmera that 1 could.

At the end of 1973 I was nominated as candidate for the ALP for the seat of Mallee. I informed Mr Tudor of this fact and he did not complain or advise otherwise except tell me not to send any political letters to newspapers as it could be inferred that I was speaking on company policy and in fact
ALP policy could be embarrassing to the company's relationship with the Country Party.

From that occasion on I never released anything to any newspaper unless it clearly stated my position as ALP endorsed candidate, in this way no inference could be drawn that I was speaking on behalf of the company.
The whole Mallee area knows that I am the endorsed ALP candidate and when I do speak there is no question that it is the ALP view that I deliver. Not the view of an insurance company.

On 15 January 1974 I received a memo from Mr Gallagher on behalf of Mr Tudor which was photo-stated among all company inspectors instructing them to strike up personal friendships among Country Party branch executives throughout Victoria and become invited to branch meetings. All inspectors were instructed to send a monthly list of all Country Party branch meetings attended and all meetings proposed to attend during the following month.

On Friday, 1 March 1974 many Mallee newspapers carried a story of my address to the Birchip branch of the Australian Labor Party concerning the governments decision to abolish the present subsidy on superphosphates. I was identified in the newspapers as the endorsed Labor candidate for Mallee.

At 3.30 p.m. on the same day, Friday, 1 March 1974, 1 received a telephone call from an inspector colleague of mine, Mr Allan Plant, of the company's Ararat branch, Mr Plant is also the Country Party candidate for the state seat of Ham den. He asked me to confirm if it was me that the newspaper report referred to. I told him it was. He then told me that it would be unlikely that Federation Insurance would view the situation favourably.

talk.start.para: What is the company— Federation Insurance
Federation Insurance Ltd. The statement continues:

quote.para: One hour and a half later at 5.00 p.m. on Friday, 1 March 1974, just as 1 was ready to finish my work for the week and go home I received a telephone call from Mr Gallagher. It went as follows:
Brian Gallagher here, I'm sorry but I will have to spoil your weekend'
I said,' Why, what's happened?'
He replied, 'Mr Tudor wants you to bring your rate books and the car to our Melbourne office first thing on Monday morning and be prepared to go back by train'.
I said, 'Why, what's happened?'
He said, ' I can't tell you that, you will have to see Mr Tudor on Monday and talk about it.'
I said, 'Then that means there is still room for talk and I don't have to bring my rate books down?'
He said, 'No, you still have to bring your rate books with you and you will be returning by train.'

I then rang Mr Paris Chambers the General Manager. He claimed he was quite surprised and was not foretold by Mr Tudor of his intentions. Mr Chambers also said that my work effort was quite good and he had heard no adverse remarks. He further stated that he had been in attendance all the week at the branch manager conference and my name had not come up for discussion. He said that my ALP endorsement was of no concern to the company but that the decision had apparently been made by Mr Tudor as a branch decision and he could not interfere.

continue.para: There are further statements in this document that I could read out, but I want to get to the crux of the whole situation. Associated with the dismissal of Mr Smith is a set-up between this company and the Australian Country Party that is rather staggering. In 1972, Federation Insurance Ltd gave $30,564.04 to the Victorian Branch of the Country Party as a backhander. In 1973, the company paid $47,257.54 to the Victorian Branch of the Country Party as another perk. In 1974 the amount is estimated to be $60,000. These are handouts from this insurance company to the Country Party. So why has the company moved in and had this man dismissed? He is a young man with a wife and 4 children who has been dismissed overnight on the basis that he dared not only to be a member of the Australian Labor Party but also to stand as an endorsed candidate for it.

But the Country Party is in a far better position than this. The Victorian Branch of the Country Party has been granted 8,858 ordinary shares of the company under option with a value of $ 17,716. The Country Party has been granted an option to purchase shares to the value of $ 17,716 in this company. Honourable senators can see the tie-up between this insurance company and the Country Party and the reason why this person who decided that he would have political freedom in the community was sacked summarily overnight by virtue of the fact that he was the endorsed candidate for the Australian Labor Party. But the position goes even further. From the next part of the statement we find that this company is completely unethical in its operations with its clients. I would suggest that the Insurance Commissioner should have the company investigated. Federation Insurance Company inspectors were told by a responsible officer of the company to tear out the centre page of the company's superannuation statutory information sheet which showed a loss of $30,051 over the last 2 years. The inspectors were not permitted to show any client they were interviewing the losses that the company had been incurring.

Whilst the company is losing this kind of money—$30,00 0 in a period of 2 years t is giving handouts by the backdoor to the Country Party of up to $60,000 a year. I believe that a company with this reputation needs to be investigated completely and absolutely by the Treasurer (Mr Crean) in order to ensure that this kind of racket will not continue in the political life of our community. The handouts are based on one of 2 factors: Either the company is too lousy and mean to pay agents and is using Country Party membership to sell its premiums or it is

charging premiums far above those that it should charge and is robbing the clients to whom it is selling insurance. So we have this situation in Victoria at least and, as the company is called the Federation Insurance Ltd the racket could be going on all over Australia. On the basis of the huge amounts that have been given out in Victoria alone, a major insurance company is giving handouts to the Country Party by the backdoor. It has handed out approximately $130,000 during 3 years of operation in its association with the Country Party.

This great democratic organisation that will not allow a man to earn a living because he happens to be a member of the Labor Party is obviously is in a situation in which rackets operate and in which it can deceive the people it wishes to have as clients to the extent that it expects its agents to cheat and lie by the removal of figures and documents from the company's statutory reports which would show that the company was losing money on certain aspects of the premiums that it wished to sell to people. I hope that, in the light of the information I have been able to provide to the Senate this evening, the company is investigated.

talk.start.para: - Speaking in reference to the speech to which we have just listened, I state that it is a matter of great regret that individual charges of that sort should be brought before the Senate as an ex parte statement of public denigration without some preliminary investigation by a committee of the Senate. I say nothing for or against the allegations to which we have listened. But I simply say that the use of parliamentary privilege for purposes of that sort is an abuse unless the honourable senator who has spoken guarantees to sustain the charges upon examination.
He has got pretty strong evidence.

A11 the cackle in the world will not gainsay the verities of what I put to the Senate. I do not propose to occupy the time of the Senate any further with that matter until there has been a proper investigation of it. I prefer to address the Senate on much more substantial matters which I hope would attract a much wider interest than individual accusations such as those which Senator Poyser has made. Senator Withers, in addressing himself to this Bill, brought before the Senate some startling information. It is being presented to the Senate for its first reading as a money bill. It is an Appropriation Bill, one of the Bills that under the Constitution the Senate is unable to amend. Therefore

continue.para: the wisdom of our forefathers provided that in our procedures we should have an unusual principle in respect of Bills of this sort; that is to say, upon their being presented for the first time we can speak upon them at undue length, for up to 1.5 hours except on the nights on which our proceedings are broadcast, and on matters which are not strictly relevant to the legislation.

Senator Withers took the course of speaking on matters relevant to the Bill and showed that it is another gulp by the Labor Party from the Treasury of another $ 186m by way of appropriation; that is to say, an appropriation not provided for in November. The Government shamefacedly confesses that this appropriation is almost entirely required because of extra costs incurred for the Public Service. Senator Withers has told us that the cost to the public so far of the extra public servants that the Government has engaged is $ 150m a year; that is an increment of $150m a year. This increase in the wages bill for the civilian Public Service takes the cost of the Public Service from $569m in 1972-73 to $802m for the current year. We live in a situation in which none of these things ever interests the media. Tonight our proceedings are broadcast and it is necessary to mention the bald facts so that some of the dairy farmers who have been deprived of their subsidy and are now about to sit down after milking their cows might understand the way in which they are being milked by the Labor Government that they took a risk in electing in December 1972.

The wages bill for Commonwealth public servants is enlarged to $802m in the current year from the already inordinate amount of about $570m in 1972-1973. As Senator Withers has told us, that is equal to a growth in the Public Service expenditure of 41 per cent in one year. In my opinion these are the startling figures of today; that is to say, an increase of $232m representing a 41 per cent increase in the wages cost of the Australian Government's Public Service. If that could be sustained by this country without producing galloping inflation and irresponsible and damaging costs, it would defy all facts. The Government is creating such extravagant expenditure on its own Public Service that unbridled inflation threatens every member of the community.

But that is not the only matter to which attention should be drawn. In the last week or so I have endeavoured to direct the attention of the Minister for Repatriation (Senator Bishop), who represents the Minister for Labour (Mr Clyde Cameron) in the Senate, to matters of dangerous and chaotic import in our industrial situation. His

only response is to take a wide sweep of Germany. He has told us that after comparative stability in the German industrial scene over the last 20 years when the poor devils were building up their own economy after the war, they have broken out and have become irresponsible. He tells us that industrial disruption has occurred in England and the United States of America. At question time this Minister shows himself to be quite unconscious of the dangerous and disastrous situation that has been reached in industrial relations in Australia. He refers to the United States of America, a country which we know has been bedevilled by an irresponsible administration of industrial law for the last 25 years and by an economy in which in the postwar period a most inflationary condition was created by rampant pressures of the unions.

In Great Britain the unions have been unbridled by law since 1906. Despite the efforts of Heath in his Bill of 1971 the paralysis in the British economy is now of such a careful nature that visitors to Britain and half of its population are almost on the brink of despair. It is because of the disastrous precedents in those countries that I intend to advocate this cause with all the vehemence I can muster before disaster befalls us. In Australia, far from inheriting the conditions of those countries, we inherited a system that is unique and precious. I refer to the system of arbitration which was legislated for in 1904 and operated with somewhat indifferent success over the years. But it was successful in creating a remarkably improved condition of life for our working people. It was successful in maintaining some semblance of law and order from an industrial point of view in disputes.

The Labor Government has come to power. It announced unashamedly first that it will not enforce the provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act where they are breached by strikes or industrial disruption. That policy gives encouragement to the substitution for a system of arbitration of the primitive form of settling industrial disputes, that is, by boycott, pressure, intimidation and monopoly power. We are reverting headlong to that ungoverned system of industrial relations simply because this Government proclaims that it will not support the arbitration system. On the one hand it creates a whole army of inspectors of police offences committed by employers in breaches of awards made through the arbitration system. But on the other hand it unashamedly proclaims that it will not enforce the provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Therefore, the Government must
accept a great degree of responsibility for the industrial chaos that now prevails.

I wonder whether it is realised in Labor Party circles that this Government, for the first time in Australia, advocated the chaos that was brought into England in 1906. In the British Trades Disputes Act a provision existed which relieved trade unions of all responsibility for damage done and wrong done only because they were done in the course of industrial disputes. The Minister for Labour (Mr Clyde Cameron) initiated the introduction of Bills which were presented twice to the Senate and which contained that provision. It is the purpose of this Government to introduce that direct contribution to industrial anarchy and to give the unions the opportunity to act completely irresponsibly in respect of any damage done and wrong done in the course of industrial disputes. That is bad enough, but every time the Government is asked to justify or to excuse its shocking performance which has resulted in industrial chaos the Minister for Labouring w echoed by the Minister for Repatriation (Senator Bishop)—say s that if the Senate had passed this legislation, which took the form of amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, the position would have been improved. The position would have been absolutely chaotic, primitive and even worse than it is now.

In my home State at present we have in southern Tasmania an industry operated by the Electrolytic Zinc Co. of Asia Ltd which for 70 years has employed some 2,000 employees. It has the reputation of being one of the best employers in Australia. The wages bill for its factory at Risdon last year was, I think, about $ 13m. The bonus paid to employees, under a sustained bonus arrangement, was $2.1m in the company's factories at Rosebery and Wisdom last year. Disruptionists have come onto the scene. A small minority group has been able to precipitate a strike on the whole of that undertaking at a time when the superphosphate being manufactured by that company is sought by farmers and other products are wanted by the newsprint mills for newsprint manufacture. A strike causing wholesale losses for those wage earners has been in progress for a fortnight.

The strike has been caused by one issue that has been imported into the zinc works by foreigners. It is a foreign issue. Those who have caused this strike want the company to subscribe to what they call an industrial agreement in lieu industrial disputes and conditions being determined by the State Wages Board system which exists in Tasmania and has been maintained and

brought up to date from time to time by a Labor Government in that State. This is only a euphemistic way for the union agitators to say: 'We do not want a tribunal to adjust our conditions. We will frustrate the tribunal and insist upon bargaining as animals bargain in the scrub', that is to say by pressure, boycott and monopoly bargaining. I think nothing could be more deplorable. Today a new disclosure has been made. The Australian Newsprint Mills Ltd, which is about 15 miles further up the Derwent River, is responsible for the employment of about 1,500 workers. That company was able to get its product moved from the factory to the mainland until November last year by the sporadic aid of international ships that call into Hobart from time to time. The unions then made the statement: 'You must not employ international ships to move interstate cargoes'. The result is that production, continuing at the rate of about 800 tons a week, is mounting up and there is now a backlog of production in the store of approximately 16,000 tons. Unless it is moved by ship within the next 2 or 3 weeks the whole works are threatened with closure. This is as a result of the absurd restrictions placed upon shipping vital to the transportation of that product from Tasmania to the places where it is to be used.

How can the Government be so stupid as to enforce a prohibition against international ships being used to carry interstate cargo when interstate ships are wholly insufficient for that purpose? On the north coast of Tasmania a similar restriction on shipping exists. The stage has been reached on the north coast that the last private enterprise ship in the trade has been notified to pay off its officers within a few weeks, which will leave only the Australian National Line services operating. I have indicated that I intend to try to persuade the Senate and the Government to reconstitute the Inter-State Commission which was the constitutional body, provided for in the Constitution, to administer laws relating to interstate trade, which would have the responsibility of seeing that economy is exercised and that efficiency is shown. There will be an agency thereafter required to give Tasmania efficient and economic shipping services.

Since the introduction of a system of grants by the Commonwealth Grants Commission, there has been a notion among a great number of people that we get compensation, by way of financial assistance, because of this shipping disability. That is a complete myth. The Commonwealth Grants Commission does not take this item into consideration in the slightest. I complain of the shocking performance of the Labor

Government in this industrial disruption. Only a fortnight ago we were threatened with a shortage of wheat because of a sustained strike at Geelong which immobilised one of the essential wheat carrying vessels which goes to Hobart.

Add to that the general scene. The metal trade workers have been on strike for 48 hours this week. There has been a threat of continuation of those strikes. There has been the performance in the rad ways this week. Then one recalls the building labourers' strikes not merely in regard to building industry disputes but in regard to disputes pertaining to other matters altogether. I say here tonight that it is imperative that the Minister becomes conscious of the fact that his Government is doing everything to paralyse and smash the arbitration system. His Government is doing everything to support his masters, the trade unions from whom his Party was spawned. His Government is giving government of the industrial sector of the country to the trade unions. The Government, the supposedly responsible Government, the elected and representative Government, sits by and gives active encouragement to this disruption which seeks to establish the old primitive process of bargaining by boycott and disruption instead of by our arbitration and wages boards system.

This situation has reached a position of peril in Great Britain, which never had an arbitration system. It has reached an insidious stage in the United States and has caused a rate of inflation which brought even that country to a position of financial danger last year. It is imperative that in Australia the Government wakes up and ensures that the element of trade unionism, which has a real function in regard to industrial organisation, does not become the substitute for government and does not make the elected Government subordinate, but that the trade union movement should be required to conduct its dispute in accordance with law, without disruption, before the arbitration tribunals and the wages boards.

talk.start.para: - I wish to take a few minutes of the Senate's time tonight to reply to what, to me, have been most extravagant speeches by Senator Wright and, more particularly, by Senator Withers who holds a very senior position in the Senate. He is the Leader of the Opposition. He attacked Commonwealth public ser vents and accused them of bludging. He attacked the Government for introducing an Appropriation Bill which seeks the appropriation of over $168m. Both honourable senators claimed that the expenditure generally is largely on salaries, and so it is. I wish to point out some of the expenditures about which they talked. Let me refer firstly to an important sector about which they have been campaigning for many months, that is the Labor Government's failure to assist the defence forces. The expenditure, as shown on page 39 of Appropriation Bill (No 3), for the Department of Defence is $5 5. 5m. It is for salaries and wages, which are necessary and which are a part of the obligation which the Government has in respect of all the Services. That is a part of the Bill which we are presenting to the Parliament tonight. But the Opposition says that it is a most extravagant Bill, the amounts are too high, and something should be done about it.

speech.para: Senator Withersattacked Commonwealth public servants. He called them fat cats. He attacked their housing subsidies. Under division 548, on page 33, the additional amount required to service the Leaders of the Opposition and the Parliamentary Parties, Deputy Leaders of the Opposition and the Whips is $ 1 1 1 ,000. It is a necessary amount. I do not disagree with it. They are some of the additional payments about which the Leader of the Opposition in this place is complaining.

talk.start.para: I see that the figure for Ministers of State is $1.5m

I am not disputing that figure, but the strange thing about the honourable senator's Party is this: Senator Withers said that Commonwealth public servants are largely non-productive. Is he saying that about the Senate? On page 4 of the Bill the additional sums necessary to service this Parliament are listed. We know how active this Parliament is, with all its committees. The amount is nearly $lm. It is a necessary amount. Does he say that the servants of the Senate, the servants of the Parliament, are non-productive? In effect, that is what he said tonight. Not only did he say that they were nonproductive but he said that they were budging on the taxpayers. 'Budging' is the most offensive word in the Australian vocabulary. I never thought that I would hear a Leader of the Opposition talk that way about Commonwealth servants who, after all, are the servants of the Government and the Parliament. They carry out the dictates of the Government and, to a large extent, the Parliament. But he called them bludgers, and he attacked the housing subsidies.

continue.para: People who are transferred to Canberra from other States and who cannot get a house must pay the high rents which private enterprise demands. They are entitled to a departmental cottage. They cannot get one. They must pay extra

rent. Because they pay extra rent they receive a subsidy, which is necessary to keep the Service going. Let me remind the Leader of the Opposition that the people who receive the subsidy include members of the defence forces. Why should not they be entitled to a housing subsidy? The wives are separated from their husbands. The men are posted to places where their homes are not and where their families are not. Why should not they be reimbursed for the high rents which they are charged, when they ought to be entitled to Government accommodation? Most of the enterprising private employers in outback places supply accommodation, generally at a lower rent than the rent which the Governmentcharges.

I just cannot understand this sort of attack on public servants. If the Leader of the Opposition had centred his attack on the very senior heads of branches, if he had said that their pay was too high, etc., there may have been something in his argument. The same comment applies to Senator Wright. They did not produce any facts and figures. No case was presented. There was no study of the position. But they attacked Commonwealth public servants and the Government.

talk.start.para: - I attacked the cost.

Of course you did. I am saying that you did. The honourable senator also attacked the need for public servants to travel first class. He demands first class travel. We want first class travel for ourselves. We get it. We use it. We have transport provided. The honourable senator said that our servants, the people who are instructed to carry out our responsibilities, should not have first class travel. We know that all these committees which the Senate has sought will mean extra costs and extra wages. We pay more for specialists. We pay more for draftsmen. Why should the Opposition not acknowledge that? Why should it not be fair? The growth of the Public Service is not new to Australia. It happened during the regimes of previous governments. It is a matter which we have to watch, but surely we do not have to attack everybody in the Public Service, people who as yet cannot reply. Generally speaking they are doing a good job and they certainly are not non-productive. They have a duty and a productive efficiency and produce something in the same way as a boilermaker, a fitter or a carpenter produces something. I resent the attacks on them. They are our servants and they should be respected. If honourable senators want to make a case out against them, let them bring in a studied case.

continue.para: In a very short statement I shall refer to what Senator Wright has talked about in relation to industry and industrial relauons. This week in his questions to me he has talked about a dispute within a State. As I pointed out today, the Federal Government can do nothing about that unless it is invited to do so by the State Labor Government or by the employers and the unions jointly seeking the assistance of the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to solve the dispute. I said I was sure— I am sure— that at the present time the Minister, his officers and I , if necessary, will be willing to assist in trying to solve the dispute. Many of us have been doing this for many years. Our attitude towards the question of employee-employer relations is based on the idea that there ought to be more conciliation and there must be more agreements. If the dispute to which Senator Wright has referred is a dispute which today rests upon the need for cementing an agreement, it may be that an agreement between the parties is better than having a State wages board determination. Under the sorts of proposals which our Government is putting forward we would like to see the employers and the workers making agreements and, during the course of those agreements, being bound to refrain from disputes and to adopt a disputes procedures clause. That is a good thing. That is the sort of thing we are aiming at and that is the sort of thing which was contained in the legislation which was previously before this Parliament but which was held up. That is the sort of proposal which the Government will shortly reintroduce.

The idea is that the bosses and the workers ought to get together and make an agreement, outside the court if necessary. But during the currency of the agreement they should agree to minimise disputes upon the matters which are to be settled. They ought to agree that there will be no stoppages and they ought to have a regular disputes procedure. That has worked in some industries. In those cases there have been agreements which have worked for several years without major disputes. That is the sort of thing we want. That is the sort of legislation which will be coming into this Senate. I hope that because of our arguments the Senate Opposition will give passage to that legislation when it comes to hand. I suppose that I have had as much experience as most people in the field of industrial disputes. Of course a situation often depends on the personality of the employer and the union leader. In the area of industrial disputes one of the worst things is to get inflammatory people making inflammatory remarks. Looking at Senator

Wright in this chamber I would not like him to be in a position where he had to settle disputes because as active and constructive as he is sometimes, he is a most militant and aggressive talker. There are circumstances where it is a matter of personality.

We know that internationally there has been the sort of situation about which the honourable senator has talked. It is a sign of the umes that when there is an inflationary position people in industry are trying to seek a remedy against rising prices. As a matter of fact, in our country, if honourable senators look at the figures they will find that while the number of disputes might have increased the number of people involved has decreased. In the United Kingdom, America, Germany and other places there is this tendency for more disputation. Labor Party policies have been designed on the basis of involving workers in management, participation in management and agreements which should run for a long time. If those agreements provide a good deal or a package deal which benefits the workers and the employers, we believe that they should run without disputation for a sub st anu al length of time. They are the objectives. They are sensible. But however sensible they may be there will always be circumstances where disputes will occur. In those circumstances the best people to solve the disputes are the people who have had experience in the field, whether the State field or the Federal field. All we can do as a government — jus t as honourable senators opposite used to do as a government s not invoke penal clauses but provide the best conciliator or arbitrator in the area, to get him quickly on to the job to help to resolve the dispute. I entered the discussion mainly because I thought the attacks on the Commonwealth Public Service were most offensive. I object to the word 'budging' and the suggestion that Commonwealth servants are budging. When that is said there is obviously a blanket assertion that every public servant is doing it, including some of our own staff.

talk.start.para: -I shall mention 3 items briefly tonight. The first one I want to deal with is the criticism that we have seen of the Senate over the last few weeks by the Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam). The second point 1 shall be dealing with will be inflation and then, briefly, I shall comment on tourism. The first thing is the criticism of the Senate by the Prime Minister. No doubt he would like every Bill which comes before this chamber to go straight through. No doubt he would like to have open slather with all his legislation so that, as quickly as possible, he could push through socialist schemes which could well prove to be irreversible, no matter how far in the future we look. Perhaps in their wisdom the people who drew up our Constitution foresaw our present Prime Minister with his desire to change everything as quickly as possible. Perhaps they knew that at some stage in the future we would need the Senate to act with judgment based upon the needs of the States rather than the political needs of the major parties. I make no apology for siding at times with those who suggest a certain slowness of action as is required by our Standing Orders and by the Constitution. Because one Party- the Australian Labor Party- received a very small surplus of seats and votes at the last election, that does not mean that that Party should have a completely open go.

speech.para: It has been my contention always that a Party does not actually win office. The Government of the day loses it. During the last year or for a bit more than a year we have heard about this Government having a mandate to do whatever it likes. To me that is just rubbish. The Government has a bare majority of some .5 per cent to one per cent. I expect that at the next Senate election we will see quite a swing against the Government. One of the reasons that I expect a swing is that the referenda questions will confuse people. In this I agree with Mr Bob Hawke 's first contention, anyway. I feel that Mr Whitlam is quite crazy having the referenda questions at the same time as the Senate election. I have said before that Mr Whitlam just does not understand figures. If he did he would not spend so much of his time overseas on ministerial trips and he would not be buying 707 aircraft for the VIP fleet. If he knew anything about figures he would be able to reduce taxes rather than continually increase them.

talk.start.para: Why does the honourable senator not stand for a seat in the House of Representatives?
Order ! Senator Townley is quite entitled to stand for any seat in either House.

In a moment I shall deal with the way in which taxes have been increased by this Government which said that it was not going to increase taxes. One thing which has interested me is why Mr Hawke switched his ideas about the referenda. I think that he realises that it will be quite a mistake to have those questions put at the same time as the next Senate election. Perhaps he wants to see Mr Whitlam make mistakes, but I will not go on with that matter

continue.para: Mr Whitlam just does not understand figures and I do not think he understands Tasmanian people very well. A few weeks ago he was silly enough to make certain pronouncements about independents in Tasmania. I am sure that he would like to have our seats but he should at least be accurate in the pronouncements he makes. The Federal government, no matter which Party is in power, is controlled from Melbourne and Sydney. Together those 2 dues hold 45 of the 123 seats in the other place; so just what hope do the votes of the 5 Tasmanian members have against those odds. In an evenly balanced Senate independent senators from Tasmania have a special role to play. They can have a lot to say and anyone saying anything else is wrong.

I refer now to inflation. We have been warned about this from many areas from almost the first few days of this Government's coming to office. In my opinion it is going to get even worse during the next few months. I think that one of my independent Tasmanian colleagues hit the nail on the head when he said that this Government is assisting a high rate of inflation on purpose, because in that way it automatically socialists us a little bit because of the cancerous tax scales. Also inflation makes it easy for the Government to get extra money for its socialist schemes.

talk.start.para: - Who was the independent Tasmanian colleague who said that?

I have seen nothing lately which would make me disagree with my colleague's assessment of the facts. In the last Budget we had a 20 per cent increase in taxes which were imposed on the community in one way or another. Taxes on cigarettes, beer, whisky and so on went up. I think i.t was only on liquor, not on beer, but maybe that increase will come this year. We saw the Government Tip-off 5c a gallon from all of us who drive. Many of us drive long distances in this country. The Government justified the increase by comparing our price for petrol with that charged in places like Switzerland or Italy. To do that is just not honest. People in those countries do not have to drive the long distances that we travel and they do not have to lug commerical goods for thousands of miles as we do in this country.

are having a lot of trouble selling their fruit. I know that there have been increases apart from the increased petrol tax, but in my opinion this Government really has not helped the apple industry a great deal. In fact I think it did a very bad thing by removing the tax exemption on carbonated drinks which contained 5 per cent of Australian fruit juice. In my opinion that was a bad decision for Tasmania.

The petrol tax increase will raise the cost of all bread and butter items. It has affected everything. I believe it has added considerably to the cost of running farms and this, I suppose, eventually will add to the cost of our food. As I said, it has affected everything. I hope that one of these days this Government or another government will see fit to alter this decision and reduce the petrol tax that has been imposed. This year we have seen an increase of about 20 per cent in tax collections by this Government which ostensibly was not going to increase taxes. Next year is the year I am particularly worried about. I do not want to hold up this Bill unduly. I will deal with other things like inflation and high interest rates at some other time. All these add a tremendous amount to our inflauon.

I want to refer briefly to tourism, which is important to my State of Tasmania. This morning we read in the Press that the Minister for Tourism and Recreation (Mr Stewart) wants to encourage more Australians to holiday at home instead of going overseas. I agree with him; we should encourage people to see Australia first. The Prime Minister said in his policy speech that his Government would encourage Australian airlines to provide cheap holidays within Australia as Australia's overseas airlines had been able to do for overseas travel. Once upon a time the Prime Minister realised that tourism was an identifiable nationally important industry but when Budget time came instead of helping to provide cheap travel in my opinion he did all that he could to clobber the travelling family man while still allowing nearly all our civil servants to travel around Australia on first-class air fares. I am not going to harp about luxury being accorded to our public servants today; that will come at another stage. At the moment the tourist industry is not getting the travellers from overseas who were coming a year or so ago. Revaluation has stopped many overseas visitors coming to this country. Even before the recent increase in air fares the high cost per mile of air travel within Australia was such that the majority of those who came here spent most of their time in Melbourne and Sydney and did not get to places like
Tasmania. Tourism could make quite a significant contribution to the economy of my State

I believe that Tasmania needs special consideration in this matter of air fares. I have mentioned before that Tasmania should get special consideration in lieu of the money that is spent by the Federal Government or by the State governments, after it is given to them by the Federal Government, on interstate highways. Also, while we in Tasmania have such dreadful airport terminals, such as those we have at Hobart, Devonport and Wynyard—

talk.start.para: - What about Launceston?

The one at Launceston is not bad. But while we have these bad terminals it means that our air fares are subsidising places like Tullamarine and the proposed new $ 1,000m airport to be built somewhere in New South Wales. If we pay the same fare cost per mile I cannot see why we cannot have better facilities. I think that Hobart airport should be upgraded to international standard. Tourism can be important to employment in Tasmania because industry is a major employer of females. It is important for women who want a job after their kids have grown up to be able to get jobs such as helping in a motel.

continue.para: I have emphasised air travel so far but 1 should say that I fully appreciate that the car is still a very important means of travel. It is important for many tourists within Tasmania and on the mainland. If the Government did a stupid thing in regard to the cost of living when it lifted the petrol tax by 5c a gallon, it really did a crazy thing when it applied the same tax to each gallon of aviation fuel. Instead of providing Australians with cheap travel within Australia, by increasing the fuel tax Mr Whitlam added some $5m to the fuel bill of Trans-Australiann Airlines aad about $5m to that of Ansett Airlines of Australia as well. This already has been reflected in the higher fares we have seen. For my State of Tasmania this action was most undesirable. Instead of helping to provide cheap travel as was promised, Mr Whitlam did the opposite and increased air fares to such an extent that fewer people will travel and fewer people will come io wonderful Tasmania. Fewer people will sty in our hotels and motels and fewer people will !n y goods in our shops. With higher internal fares we will see more Melbourne and Sydney people opting for a holiday via Qantas Airways to Singapore on one of the special flights that are available. Fewer people will come down to share with us the beauty of Tasmania and fewer Tasmanians will be able to afford to go to places like

Singapore because of the higher fares from Hobart, Launceston, Devonport or Wynyard to the non hern ports on their route. The Commonwealth Government evidently has no intention of helping Tasmania in relation to this matter of air fares. It has been manifest for years that air services across Bass Strait should be on a commuter basis, without meals or drinks being served in flight. But we have seen no effort on the part of the Government to give Tasmania that special attention, that special consideration, which we deserve because we are so entirely dependent on air and sea transport. This is an obvious disadvantage when it is compared with the fact that people in the other States can choose either rail, air or car as a means of communication.

Young people find it difficult to afford the cost of air travel. Young people attract very little Government assistance. I hope that the Government realises the need to provide basic accommodation for this travelling age group. Places such as youth hostels are not nearly numerous enough. Because so many young people travel long distances by car, the extra petrol tax has been an unwelcome addition to their costs.

What of the future? The Government unwisely intends to extract from the airlines the full cost of operating airports. But what of the millions of dollars extra tax received via the money spent by tourists in motels and shops all over the country when they travel to different areas of Australia by the airlines. To me it would make economic sense to allow some loss on the airport operations in order to encourage the tourists to travel about. When they arrive at their destination in other parts of Australia they will spend their dollars and thus make a contribution to the Treasury because of the extra income received in the places where they spend their money. In 1972, $139m was spent in this way. It would also make economic sense, I feel, to start allowing for depreciation on hotels and motels so that we can see sufficient investment in these important areas to cater for future requirements. This would also enable hotel and motel accommodation rates to be lower, thus making travelling for the family man just that little bit easier. If we are to have the number of hotel rooms that has been projected as being needed in the 1980s then I feel that the Government should be looking at the possibility of giving direct financial aid through grants and loans and guarantees to Australian owned companies. Incidentally, I completely agree with the principle of full Australian ownership in this area. Australians do not get much benefit if Americans fly here on American airlines, stay at American hotels and then fly home on American
airlines. I think we should have full Australian ownership of hotels.

Australian has some of the world's greatest attractions. Let us be long sighted about their development. The costs will be small and the returns to the community, I believe, will be quite large. Let us see co-operation, too, between the Treasury and the other government departments so that we will see that Australians travel about and see their own country first.

talk.start.para: - I want to take the opportunity on the motion for the first reading of the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1973-74 to refer to a couple of matters. Firstly, I would like to refer to some of the statements made by Senator Poyser earlier in this debate. I did not hear all he said, but I understand that he attacked Federation Insurance Ltd and attacked particularly the Victorian Branch of the Australian Country Party. Federation Insurance Ltd is an Australian owned and controlled insurance company. It is one of the few insurance companies in Australia that is entirely owned and controlled in Australia. It deals with many organisations, and the Victorian Branch of the Country Party happens to be one. I know also that it has agreements with other political organisations and many primary producer organisations such as wheat boards, wheat growers and other people of that type. It makes no secret whatever of its premium refunds; they are widely publicised. It carries on business all over Australia, and it saves on advertising and many other things. Many organisations insure with Federation Insurance Ltd, including some trade unions. Why do we not go a little further and look at the operations of the Australian Council of Trade Unions? It receives rebates from its major suppliers of goods, and much of this money passes as profits from the ACTU back to the Victorian Branch of the Australian Labor Party. We have no objection to an inquiry being held into Federation Insurance Ltd or any other insurance company, provided there is also an inquiry into Bourke's store, and why they receive such large discounts. An inquiry should be held also into the ACTU travel service which is trying to obtain discounts and rebates in order to provide cheap travel for its members. There is nothing wrong with that at all. But why should one organisation be attacked and no reference be made to the others?

speech.para: I want to refer also to the appropriation for the Postmaster-General's Department in this Appropriation Bill. Strange to say, the Postmaster-General's Department is not mentioned in this particular Appropriation Bill. I know that I will be told that it has a one line appropriation, that money can be transferred from one section of the Postmaster-General's Department to another without reference to the Parliament. One would think that there would be a very high wages content in that one line appropriation. Since the main purpose of this Appropriation Bill is to provide extra money for wages, one would think that the Postmaster-General's Department would figure a fair bit in this.

I want to refer particularly to a couple of matters related to the Postmaster-General's Department. I refer, firstly, to its telephone services. When the previous government was in power we had quite a good policy in relation to country telephones: Fifteen miles of line was constructed free of charge and for distances more than that the line was constructed at a very cheap rate; and it was maintained in perpetuity. This had to be the case because of the high standard of line required for automatic telephone exchanges. Some progress was being made under the previous Government in providing services for those who, by their very occupation or the place in which they lived, whether it was by accident or otherwise, required a telephone service of their own. They were not like the people who had access to public telephones in the next street or a telephone in the neighbour's place.

In Australia there is a very large number of telephone exchanges which operate on restricted hours. When one goes to other parts of the world and talks about one's telephone service being cut off at 6 p.m. or 8 p.m. and not starting again until 8 o'clock or 9 o'clock in the morning and a telephone service which finishes at midday on Saturday with no other service until Monday morning apart from possibly a short time on Sunday, one is just laughed at. One is not believed. People overseas do not believe that any place could be so backward as far as its telephone service is concerned. When we were in government we were beginning to get away from these restricted hours by putting in automatic telephone exchanges and by helping people with the construction of their telephone lines. It all came to an end with the change of Government.

talk.start.para: They are still putting them in

They are hastening very slowly, and at the rate at which automatic exchanges are being built at the present time, it will be the end of the century before these restricted telephone hours are eliminated. I have mentioned before the case of a man who lives not very far from a big city. He happens to live

continue.para: about 14 kilometres from the new exchange. He has been told that if he pays $2,000 he can get a telephone connected when the Department is ready to put it in in perhaps two or three or four years. He has to pay the $60 connection fee, the same as everybody else. We live in a Commonwealth where everything is supposed to be shared. Therefore, why should this man have to pay $2,000 now to get a service which in perhaps X number of years will provide him with the same service as is now available to people who live closer to the exchange? The limit for free construction is now 5 miles or 8 kilo meters. This makes things very unjust for some sections of our population. The postal section is a bit different in that respect. We do not have to charge people $1.50 or something like that to send a letter to a place like Birdsville to which delivery, we are told, does cost that amount. It still cost 7c—fo r the time being, anyhow. But some postal officials have told us that in the next Budget it will be increased to at least 10c. One can imagine that if a person has to pay 10c for a stamp every time he posts a letter that he is not going to write many letters. It is a far cry from the day 130 years ago or so when the penny post was introduced in the United Kingdom and they got so much revenue and could hardly cope with with amount of mail that they got at the cheaper standard postage rate.

talk.start.para: - Andrew Fisher introduced penny postage here.

Yes-and a lot of other people increased it afterwards. I would like to carry on a bit further about the mails. We have had a glaring example of union control or dictation whereby the Postmaster-General was compelled to cut out Saturday morning mail deliveries. He did not just cut out Saturday morning mail deliveries; he closed all official post offices. We have the spectacle of the post offices being closed. Once they could not give out mail there was not much more they could do, I suppose. But instead of the people now getting deliveries twice a day and once on Saturday as they used to get not too many years ago, they get 5 deliveries a week. But the overall situation is worse than that. The non-official post offices, which are remaining open, are not allowed to give out mail over the counter. Many small towns and villages do not have a household delivery service; everybody—mayb e 120 or 150 families—goe s to the post office to collect mail. If the bag arrives the Postmaster sorts the mail, puts it into pigeon holes and the people can come in, look over the counter and see it. But they are not allowed to collect it.

continue.para: District postal officers in the various bigger centres have issued official instructions to all non-official post offices in these terms: 'On no account are you to give out any mail over the counter on Saturday mornings.' As a result many of these small post offices that do not have a telephone exchange have nothing to do on Saturday morning. I saw a circular which was going around the other day asking them to report on whether it was wise to keep the post offices open. So I foresee that soon they will have all post offices shut on Saturday mornings. If they are not shut, what can they do? They cannot give out mail; they can probably only sell a few stamps and postal notes. Many of them are not money order offices. For that reason the post office and the postal service have gone downhill very much in the last 7 or 8 weeks.

There is more to it than that. When we get away from the big cities we find that many mail services come in on Friday nights and Saturday mornings and that people come in from the rural areas, mining camps and other places like that to get lihir mail but find they cannot get it until Monday mornington d so they have to make another trip to the post office. The mail is not sorted into boxes on Saturday mornings. If a small post office has a few boxes, the mail is not sorted into them. The officials are not allowed to sort or give out any mail. So some officials, rather than cause embarrassment to or have trouble with the local people, have requested that the mail bag that usually comes out late on Friday night or Saturday morning be not sent to them but held in the main post office until the Monday morning and then sent out. But there is more to it than that. They are not allowed to sort mail anywhere at all on Saturday mornings, although employees are now asking for overtime for Sunday sorting. Because they are not allowed to sort mail on the Saturday, as I said, they cannot make up mail bags for the mail contractors who go out to farms, station properties, mining camps and smaller places all around the countryside. We have got ourselves into such a fix with our mails that when the postage is increased to 10c—w e are told it will be something like that-

talk.start.para: - Who told you that?
How do you know that it true
We can only assume that what we read in the newspapers has some grain of truth in it. They are instructed what to do.
- What would you do in the circumstances if you were in government?

speech.para: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Wood)-Order!

talk.start.para: I believe that if we were in government now we would insist that the public be given a better service than they are getting now. We would see that there was no union—
- What would you do?

speech.para: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT-
Senator McLaren,you are most persistent in your interjections. If you persist any further on that line I will take action.

talk.start.para: A s I was saying, we would certainly resist union domination and dictation as to how the services of this country are to be run. We would go on trying to give a good service to all sections of the community with regard to mails, telephones and the whole telecommunications system. I again refer to the fact that the Postmaster-General is not men do ned in this Appropriation Bill but that I am taking the opportunity to speak on this Bill, which the Senate cannot amend, to voice some of my grievances on this matter.

- I recall that prior to the last election when his Party became the Government, Mr Whitlam made a statement that he had to admit that there was a vein of authoritarianism inside the Labor Party. That vein of authoritarianism has been illustrated by the fact that we now have in Australia a government which for the first time in history has decided to tell Australians whom they can play sport against and whom they cannot play sport against. I refer to the announcement that the Lawn Tennis Association of Australia has been pressured by the Government and told that it should not send a team of women to South Africa to play tennis. A statement that I heard tonight is to the effect that this organisation- a voluntary organisation which in my view is not subject to Government dictation- has been instructed that this tour should not take place. I regret the fact that it did not tell the Government that voluntary sport is controlled by the people who run the sport and not by governments. They have pointed out that should South Africa win through to the finals of the Davis Cup, under that ruling Australia would have to forfeit the Davis Cup by not playing against South Africa.
The could play on neutral ground
Oh no. The Government's attitude is that our team should not play South Africa. It is not a question of the ground.

continue.para: Surely it has reached the limit when a government starts to tell people: 'You can play sport against this country, this country and this country but you cannot play it against others'.

Some time ago the Australian Government refused to permit teams from Taiwan to come to Australia. It said to the people concerned: 'You are not allowed to play them.' A female athlete who was allowed to run in the Olympic Games and who wanted to come to Australia was not allowed to come here because the dictatorial Government said no. We have had the example of the Government telling the Australian people that they can have this cricket team here but they cannot have that cricket team here. I think we have reached an extraordinary stage when a government, which surely has enough on its hands ih dealing with inflation and all the other policies which it-has put forward and which have failed, is devoting itself to instructing the Australian people whom they can play sport against

The alleged reason that has been put forward is that there is a denial of human rights in South Africa. We have all heard of Solzhenitsyn and his book. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Willesee) has expressed shock at the disgraceful denial of human rights to millions of people in the Soviet Union. I would at least have some respect for our Government if it were consistent and if it said: 'Because there is a denial of human rights in South Africa the cricketers, footballers and tennis players cannot go there,' and because if it also said: 'Because that happens in Russia and we are all shocked at what Solzhenitsyn has revealed, our footballers, cricket teams and others cannot go to Russia.' But if the Russians were to send a soccer team to Australia tomorrow then all the people who today say to the people that they cannot play sport against countries in which human rights are denied would be in the front seats applauding vociferously the people who come from Russia and countries like Czechoslovakia where liberty does not exist today. Teams are sent out from Czechoslovakia and Ministers in the Commonwealth Government go along to the match, sit in the front seats and applaud; yet Czechoslovakia is the one country in which there is less reliance on human rights than in any other country.

talk.start.para: - It is not as bad as in Spain.
I will tell you what I think about it and what they think about it in Spain.
- And in Portugal too.
I will mention Portugal too, and the honourable senator will wish that he

continue.para: had not mentioned it. I believe that there should not be bans of this nature on sport or the arts. I think that we should allow people associated with the arts to come to Australia from any country because art should be above this kind of political ban. The people who are most prominent in banning this kind of thing are those who claim that they stand for the utmost freedom and that any moving picture, no matter what it is like, ought to be shown here.

Spain and Portugal were mentioned. I was in Spain 2 years ago, at a time when the people were holding demonstrations for the 35 th anniversary of the defeat of communism by General Franco. I arrived there after the celebrations. But when I arrived there, on the day of the great celebration of the saving of Spain from the communists, the star attraction in Madrid was the Moscow Ballet. When I said to some Spaniards that this was rather strange they said: 'Look, sport and art should be above these kinds of bans.' An honourable senator mentioned Portugal. When I went to Lisbon our Ambassador told me that the matter causing the utmost excitement at the time was the fact that the top Portuguese soccer team, Benfica, had been invited to tour the Soviet Union. What governments could dislike one another more than the governments of Spain and Portugal and the government of the Soviet Union? Yet they have enough sense to put sport and the arts above that kind of political ban.

Who is going to tell me that a South African cricketer is a racist? The South African cricketers may well be people who are entirely opposed to any form of racism or apartheid. When our Australian teams play overseas teams we do not play the governments; we play the representatives of the ordinary people in those countries. I think it is a scandal that in a country like Australia that is supposed to be free there is the Whitlam Government bringing in legislation which calls for more and more power for Canberra and adding unnecessary things like telling our tennis players, footballers and cricketers whom they can play against. I do not support for one moment any person who says that we should bring this kind of attitude into sport or the arts. I do not support those who sometimes say: 'Let us keep the Russian Ballet out because of Stalin and Khrushchev.' The Russian Ballet is the highest form of ballet in the whole world. Why should
we deprive ourselves of being able to see that high form of art perhaps because a government says: 'There is a denial of human rights in Russia, therefore let us keep the Russian Ballet out.'

The final point that I want to mention is connected with sport too. I am sorry to see that the Australian Government proposes to make a sum of money available for a team of Australian footballers to go to certain countries. I will tell the Senate why I feel sorry. I support Australian football. I hold the No. 1 ticket for the North Melbourne club, which will be the premiers in Melbourne this year. I believe that in Australia today many clubs are having a tough trot particularly in my own State of Victoria. Teams in the country cannot carry on. One big team in the Victorian Football League is wondering whether it can carry on. These trips to Europe, where soccer and rugby are well entrenched, cannot achieve anything by way of promotion. They are just joy rides. I have no objection to private companies which have financed these joy rides; that is their business. But if the Australian Government has money to spend on this sort of thing let it spend it on encouraging the Australian game inside Australia and if there is any money left over let us encourage Australian football where it already has a foothold n New Guinea, where it has a flourishing competition. Let us encourage it in the areas near our shores where promotion has a real chance—wh o am I to deny the players a gift from Father Christmas? They are going to get a free trip, but from the point of view of promotion it will be meaningless. If the money is available, then I say we should use it to encourage the Australian game inside Australia and in the countries close to our shores where there is a chance of doing something for development.
